# Day 1136

**How Do You Find Your Flow State?**

Focus is rare thing in today's world.
Not because people don't want to focus, but because the entire modern world is engineered to prevent it.

The internet is an infinite buffet of distractions. Open Instagram, Twitter, TikTok, YouTube and you're immediately doused in dopamine.

A firehose of algorithmically refined distractions masquerading as engagement. But this isn't flow. This is consumption.

Flow is creation. Flow demands you become the firehose rather than the thirsty mouth gaping beneath it.

![](https://miro.medium.com/0*Wj27tgbfSjP-bkVU)

True flow state isn't found in the swipe-and-scroll paralysis of infinite feeds, but in the friction of deliberate focus. Its prerequisites are non-negotiable: You need a mission that matters (not a distraction that numbs) and a ruthless elimination of anything competing for your mental bandwidth.

Passion isn't optional here. If you don't have a deep love for the thing you are doing then you are guaranteed to burn out. Passion is the jet fuel that makes the grueling ascent into flow possible.

If you do not have a passion for what you are doing the gravitational pull of notifications, "quick checks," and artificial urgency will inevitably yank you back to Earth and out of the flow state.

This is why flow feels elusive: It requires sacrificing the shallow gratification of reacting to others' priorities (your boss's Slack message, a viral trend) to fully inhabit your own.

The artist doesn't achieve flow while monitoring likes on their last post. The programmer doesn't slip into the zone with email pings slicing through their concentration. Flow is territorial. It demands you defend your attention like a wolf guarding its kill.

The paradox? What looks like discipline from the outside, turning off phones, blocking apps, working in monastic isolation, isn't willpower at all when you're lit by genuine interest. Having a true love for the thing you are doing will help transform your sacrifice into salvation.

You're not "avoiding TikTok" but protecting something more vital: Your capacity to dissolve into an activity so completely that time distorts, self-consciousness evaporates, and you remain completely engaged in what you are doing until you snap out of that flow state.

Social media is just cheap candy for the brain: a sugar high that leaves your fingers twitchy and your hunger gnawing again before you reach the end of your feed.

Flow is meat you hunted yourself, eaten with dirty hands still shaking from the fight, a fullness that lingers for hours.

Cheap dopamine leaves you restless. Hard work doing the thing you love leaves you revelatory.

One numbs you to life. The other awakens you to yourself.

5/1/25

Conor Jay Chepenik
